title: Total Cookie Protection Blocking Single Sign Out
content:
My website uses Single Sign Out using a Front Channel SSO URL. This requires the browser to navigate to my application in an iFrame from another website, passing along with my site's authentication cookie, so my website can sign the user out. I have this cookie set to SameSite=none & Secure=true, so it can be transmitted cross-site. However, Total Cookie Protection, which is the default setting on Firefox, is blocking this cookie, which causes the Single Sign Out feature to fail. If I lower the setting to just "Cross-site tracking cookies", the cookie does get properly transmitted, but I cannot expect all of my users to know to go into their settings to enable this.

What can I do to allow Single Sign Out from a Front Channel URL to work in the default Firefox settings? This is not a problem with the default Chrome settings. Thank you.
creator: efinch

title: Bookmarks Toolbar & Graphics Glitches in Latest Version
content: After upgrading to the latest version (112.0.1) on MacOS 10.15.7, the bookmarks toolbar disappears when I enter fullscreen mode ('Always Show' is selected under Bookmarks Toolbar in the View menu). When I exit fullscreen mode, the toolbar reappears but a large grey bar then appears at the top of the window (see screenshot). I've read answers in the knowledge base that suggest that the toolbar always disappears in fullscreen mode, but I am 100% sure that this behaviour did not exist before the recent upgrade (perhaps this behaviour has been around for a while in Windows?). Either way the grey bar is clearly a bug and feels related to the toolbar behaviour. Has anyone else experienced this?

creator: sonicanimal

title: Unified Extension Button inefficiency
content:
Hi, I would like to join the chorus and say that the unified extensions button really needs to be fixed somehow. I can't stand it -- it slows down my workflow and seems like "change for change's sake".

But if you guys are serious that it can't be removed for some reason, then at least PLEASE make the unified extensions thing something that can be expanded horizontally along the toolbar (instead of just being a dropdown list) with preferred / most used extension icons visible in it, so that instead of

>clicking the unified extensions thing >scrolling down to find my extension >right clicking on the extension >choosing the option I want

It will just be

>click on the extension icon in the special unified extension section of the toolbar >the options for the extension pop up and I can choose one JUST LIKE THE OLD WAY THAT WAS EFFICIENT

I wouldn't even be opposed to an entire Extensions Toolbar with super security or whatever built into it. As long as the icons are still conveniently located and accessible!

I have a bunch of extensions that I don't need to interact with regularly, like my adblocker, https everywhere, or the thing to make webpages appear in dark mode. But every time I click the unified extensions thing they're right there at the top of the list. My screenshot extension however (for example), which I use constantly, is somewhere hidden near the bottom of the list, so I'm constantly scrolling down awkwardly looking for it. It used to be one button click to take a screenshot, now it's like five or six clicks and takes around 20+ seconds every time. IT'S VERY BAD USABILITY DESIGN. It might "feel" cleaner or more organized to put everything in a list, but it's not as functional for the end user (in my opinion).

Please reconsider your design of this thing and investigate the possibility of keeping certain extensions visible on the toolbar somehow to remain easily accessible to the user. Hopefully I've been able to explain my concerns to you. Anyway, I still love Firefox on the desktop, but if you guys can fix this that would be great.
creator: Mammon

title: Change location so Google Search & Google Maps work properly
content:
Hi all,

I just started working from home for a UK branch of an USA company. My work involves having to use VPN to their USA head office. It all works fine. My location is obviously incorrect showing that my computer is located in the USA in their home city. I understand that.

It causes me problems with Google Search because it always show me USA based results, not UK based results. I need to be able to force Google to show me results from the UK. No, going to www.google.co.uk doesn't work, it still shows me the USA biased results.

To a lesser extent, it causes me problems with Google Maps as it keep on searching the wrong areas and returning the wrong results/directions.

I understand the VPN is causing the location issue, I am not disputing that. I am asking how to make Firefox show Google my actual location, please? I'd much prefer to avoid browser extensions. I tried changing "geo.provider.network.url" in "about:config". https://browserleaks.com/geo shows the fixed location, i.e., the location I put in. However, Google isn't fooled by this and still show me the wrong location in the USA.

Any way to force Google to show me the correct location, please? Many thanks.
creator: me119

title: Drag and drop image in Windows can result in a very difficult to remove file
content:
This is an issue that goes back many years and continues to today. It has wasted countless hours for Windows Firefox users that end up with a file that they cannot easily remove.

Here are some steps you can follow to recreate the issue:

  1. Open Firefox and search for die nanny svg
  1. Click the Images button
  1. Right-click the image at the "Wikipedia" link (see attached) and select Open Image in New Tab.
  1. Go to the new tab and you'll see that URL is a base64 encoding of the above preview.
  1. Drag the image to a folder and it should then create the problematic very long file name.

Please note that performing that last step (i.e. dragging the image to a folder) works without any issue in Edge and Chrome. That is, it just creates a "download.png" file. But in Firefox, it creates this filename:

data image_png;base64,iVBORw0KGgoAAAANSUhEUgAAARwAAACxCAMAAAAh3_JWAAABsFBMVEX_853_oIQAAADc9fgOKz_I6ffXann_9Z7_+aH_+6L_957i+_7P8f__moL_nIP__qSBl5_a9f3_o4b_85fR8_+pxdEAHDTl__+MRU8NKDsAJjvs4ZGLnJ5wgorgbn7_pokjAABhcXhSX2XYzoUAJDwLIjIAFzH_15T_zZH_u4z47JkIG

  1. That long filename cannot be easily deleted. These are the steps to delete it:
  1. Shift-right-click the file name in Explorer and select Copy as path.
  1. Open a Cmd window (⊞-R cmd)
  1. Enter del \\?\ and then right-click to paste in the copied path. The result should look something like this: del \\?\"C:\Users\SomeUser\Downloads\DATAIM~1.URL"
  1. Press Enter to delete the file.

Please change Firefox so that it does not create these long filenames. They are creating unnecessary grief.
creator: lesferch

title: /dev/ttyACM0 port error after firefox upgrade
content: I have a localhost website that calls a peripheral device through /dev/ttyACM0. This was working fine until I upgraded ubuntu and firefox. Now I get port error: port not found. I use a compiled C program to call the peripheral device and pass variables. It still works fine from the command line and also if I imbed within a php program and call that program from the terminal. However, if I call that through firefox browser as in localhost/program.php this no longer works. I think I have firefox 113 now. I believe based on the behavior this is not a problem with php or ubuntu but is specific to firefox. I've tried to change permissions but no luck. don't see any documentation specific to this issue. Let me know if you know the solution or can suggest things to try.
